body.p: Sooda (Simple Object-Oriented Data Access) is an Object-To-Relational Mapping software for the .NET environment. O/R Mapping Software enables you to express your business rules without using SQL at all.

Sooda is a code generator, which can to generate entire Data Access Layer for your application. Each class that's generated as part of the DAL typically corresponds to a database table, its properties map to database columns and relationships map to object references and collections.
Sooda supports the following features, which are explained in the following sections:

ul.li: mapping one or more tables to a class
one-to-many and many-to-many relationships mapped as strongly typed collections
inheritance (two models: table-per-hierarchy (TPH) and table-per-subclass (TPS))
strongly-typed, database-based enumerations
lazy loading
differential serialization and deserialization of uncommitted changes (enables long-running transactions)
strongly typed query language (based on C# operator overloading)
text-based query language - SOQL
vertical partitioning of data (load-on-demand for large columns)

body.p: The following development tools/build environments are supported:

ul.li: Visual Studio 2005 (.NET Framework 2.0)
Visual Studio 2003 (.NET Framework 1.1)
NAnt 0.85

body.p: .NET Framework 1.0 is NOT supported.
The following RDBMSes are supported:

ul.li: Microsoft SQL Server 2000, 2005 (including MSDE and SQL Server Express Edition)
MySQL v4.x
PostgreSQL v8.x
Oracle 8i, 9i, 10g

body.p: Most applications written in high-level languages use the object-oriented approach. It is incompatible with the relational(tabular) model used in the databases and mapping from tables to objects is required. Traditionally programmers have written their own data access layers (DALs) which encapsulated the details of the underlying database and table-to-class mapping and provided object-oriented interface.

The goal of the mapping is to store the values of object properties in the appropriate columns of database tables. Assuming your object's properties are all primitive values (such as integers, strings, date/time, booleans) we could provide a "natural" mapping where:

ul.li: each object is stored in a single row in a particular table
each property is stored in a single column
the type of the column reflects the type of the property

body.p: Assuming we have the following database table:
body.code: create table Customer ( ID int primary key not null, Name varchar(64), Salary decimal, HireDate datetime, Active bit );
body.p: The natural mapping turns it into a class which implements the following interface:
Natural mapping is not always possible/desirable and therefore we need a mapping schema to fully describe the mapping for tables/columns/datatypes and more. We can for example:

ul.li: use other name for database table (for example TblPerson instead of Person). There are some reserved SQL keywords which cannot be used as table names (SELECT, FROM, WHERE, GROUP)
use other names for database columns (for example hire_date instead of HireDate). Some databases have limitations on the maximum column names so you might want to make them shorter.
use other datatypes (such as a column of type "integer" instead of "bit" to store the value of the "Active" property where "true" is represented by 1 and "false" is represented by 0)

body.p: The identity of entities in the database is established by their primary keys. In object-oriented languages we refer to objects by using their references. The references are short-lived and are usually valid only for a single execution of the program and as such they cannot be stored in a database directly, so the O/R mapper needs to convert between primary/foreign key values and object references when loading or storing the data.

This implies that in order to participate in O/R mapping each database table needs to have one or more primary key columns (either natural or surrogate) and you need to tell the mapper which columns are primary keys. The primary keys must be properly maintained in the database (the best way is to create a UNIQUE index on primary key columns). If you fail to do so (for example when there are many rows sharing the same value in the primary key column), you may get all sorts of undefined behavior.

Sooda provides reference identity guarantee for objects retrieved from the database. That means that if we make 2 or more queries which retrieve a particular row from the database in the same transaction they are guaranteed to be be mapped to the same object so
Object.ReferenceEquals(o1, o2) == true
There are other O/R Mapping products which only guarantee object value equality, so the same row retrieved from the database in multiple queries can be mapped to more than one row, so you only get:
o1.Equals(o2) o2.Equals(o1)
but
Object.ReferenceEquals(o1, o2) == false

section.title: One-To-Many Relationships
Mapping Multiple Tables to a Single Class

body.p: In order to use Sooda in your project you need to have a working database. We'll be using Microsoft SQL Server and the Northwind database. We'll also need to provide Sooda with the following information:

ol.li: Mapping schema that describes the mapping between tables/columns in your database and classes/properties. It is stored in an XML file, usually named SoodaSchema.xml.
Code generation parameters which specify various aspects of code generation. The settings are stored in an XML file with .soodaproject extension.
Runtime configuration parameters such as database connection string, connection type and SQL dialect - typically stored in your Application.exe.config

body.p: In addition, you need to make a small modification to your database (namely add a table that will manage primary keys). The following sections will describe the required setup in detail.

O/R Mapping Schema defines the mapping between CLI classes and database tables. You typically map each table in the database to a class, but you can also designate some table to be used for resolving the many-to-many relationship, specify that a class is to be based on multiple tables or describe a inheritance ("is-a") relationship.

The schema is contained in an XML file that is the input to SoodaStubGen utility which generates class stubs. You can write the XML file by hand or you can use a tool, such as SoodaSchemaTool to generate it for you by reverse-engineering the database. Note that it's not possible to generate the mapping schema in a automated manner, because there are things that simply aren't stored in the database, but the tools can give you a good approximation of the actual schema.
The schema is defined in an XML file, whose root is the element with the appropriate namespace. The child elements of the define classes, relations and so on, as described below.

Data Sources are defined with the element. A data source represents a connection to the database (or other store) where entities are stored. Each data source has a name and type. Sooda currently supports only Sql Data Source, but it is (theoretically) possible to add more data source types. Unless specified otherwise, the default data source for a class or relation is "default", which you need to have defined.
Until Sooda supports other data source types, the typical declaration that should occur at the beginning of each mapping schema is:

You can define additional SQL-based data sources for example to connect to multiple databases at once. Sooda will keep a single connection to each data source, but won't create one until you use an object that's based on the data source.

Classes are defined using the element. Each class is based on a number of tables, each represented by a element. Each has a name, which is used during code generation to produce the a set of C# or VB classes and other attributes which specify its runtime behavior. The following table lists available attributes of the element.

tr.td: Class name - used by SoodaStubGen to generate the class skeleton, stub, a number of related classes (factory, list wrapper, typed queries and so on)

Specifies the approximate number of instances of this class (number of rows in a table). Possible values are:
Small - up to 20-30
Medium - more than Small, up to 200-300
Large - more than few hundred
The default value is Medium. You may want to specify other values as a hint to the cache optimizer. Other than that, this value is not used.
Specifies the name of the data source for this class. The default name is "default".

Specifies the name of the base class that this class should inherit from. By default each class N inherits from N_Stub which in turn inherits from SoodaObject. Set this option to make the stub class inherit from some other class. Note that the class must ultimately inherit from SoodaObject (either directly or indirectly).

Name of the property that provides the displayable "identity" of the object. For example the "Person" class might have a label of "Name" or "Email", the "Location" might have a label of "Address". This is used to generate the default implementation of ToString() for object.

Specifies a method that will be used to generate primary keys for newly created objects. The following options are supported:
guid - generate GUID keys in-memory by calling Guid.NewGuid()
integer - pregenerates integer keys in the database by storing them in the KeyGen table. This is the default.
long - pregenerates long (64-bit) keys in the database by storing them in the KeyGen table.
alternatively you can provide a name of the class that implements IPrimaryKeyGenerator that will provide primary keys. This can call a webservice or use other means necessary to generate keys in a coordinated manner, guaranteeing that no two sessions will ever get the same primary key.
Inherits from the specified class. This parameter is explained in the section.

Specifies the default precommit value for this class. This is the value that will be INSERT'ed into the database for each not-nullable column that doesn't have a value specified. You can override it on the level.
Specifies the value of the subclass selector field that determines this object type. This parameter is explained in the inheritance section.
Specifies the name of the subclass selector field that determines this object type. This parameter is explained in the inheritance section.
Caching hint. The actual interpretation depends on the caching policy that's in place.
Collection caching hint. The actual interpretation depends on the caching policy that's in place.
Disable type cache for this type. This parameter is described in the inheritance section
Determines whether triggers should be generated for this class.

Determines whether instances of this class should be read-only. No property setters are generated in such case and some scenarios are optimized. **** TODO - TO NIE DZIA쥱 - IMPLEMENTOWA CZY WYRZUCI ?****

body.p: elements are used to define the mapping from database tables to classes and relations. Each class is based on at least one element. Each table consists of a number of elements which represent columns in a database and properties in C#/VB. Each table must have at least one field which is marked as primary key. It can have more than one (they are then called compound primary keys), but tables with zero primary keys are not allowed.
The typical definition of a class that's based on a single table looks like this:
The details about the elements are discussed in the next section.

Objects may need to be stored in multiple tables for efficiency reasons. In the following example we have two tables - one has person's ID, Name and Location, the other holds her PictureBlob (potentially very large piece of binary data that encodes the person's photo). By storing the picture in a separate table we can avoid reading from it until the data is actually needed.
This piece of schema might represent it:

Each is a unit for the load operation, which means whenever you access one field from a table, the entire table gets loaded and is cached for further accesses. This is easy way to implement fine-grained lazy loading by splitting your fields in groups that are always accessed together.

We can even have two elements that are bound to the same physical database table. You only need to repeat the primary key field in each . This allows for column-based lazy loading without the need to create additional database tables.

We have 4 objects: Adam (with primary key 1), Eva (with primary key 2), Mary (with primary key 3), John (with primary key 4). Let's assume they are represented by the corresponding variable names and see how lazy loading works as we access their properties and display them.
elements define the mapping between database columns and object properties. Each field represents a single column.
The following attributes are available on the element:

tr.td: Field name - used by SoodaStubGen to generate the C#/VB.NET property
Name of the database column. If it is not specified, Sooda assumes this is the same as 'name'

Data type. The following data types are supported:
Name C# Type Database Type Comments
Integer
int
SqlInt32
Nullable<int>
int (32-bit) For databases that dont't support 32-bit integers (such as Oracle) you can use the appropriate numeric type
Long
long
SqlInt64
Nullable<long>
bigint (64-bit) For databases that dont't support 64-bit integers (such as Oracle) you can use the appropriate numeric type
Boolean
bool
SqlBoolean
Nullable<bool>
bit The data provider should return the value in response to calling IDataReader.GetBoolean().
BooleanAsInteger
bool
SqlBoolean
Nullable<bool>
int The database stores true as 1 and false as 0. When reading any value other than zero is considered "true" and zero is considered "false"
Decimal
decimal
SqlDecimal
Nullable<decimal>
decimal

body.p: There's no support for compound properties (that would map to more than one field), but it's relatively easy to do it by hand by adding a new property of the required type.
